Yes, said Hamilton, the president is commander in chief of the military. But this power is only "occasional": when the legislature has authorized the military for actual service. He has no power to declare war or to raise and regulate armies. All these powers "appertain to the legislature." Finally, he reminds us, if any powers are abused-such as the power of pardon-the president can be impeached immediately. 
 
 One gathers from these passages a vision of the president as a temporary manager, doing only what the legislature approves, always under the relentless threat of impeachment. Presidents would come and go, and they would be in fear of the legislature. One misstep and they could be tossed out. Oh, and by the way, the president can't get rid of the legislature except in one narrow case: he can adjourn them when they otherwise can't agree on how or when to leave. 

 
 Besides Clinton, there has only ever been one other US president impeached...Andrew Johnson. He was impeached for attempting to remove his secretary of war from office without congressional approval. Talk about a nothing offense...but he was impeached for it.
 
 For the vast majority of our nations history, our presidents have walked a damn thin line. Up until WWII, the office of the president did not hold much by way of real power. What are the presidents constitutional powers? He can negotiate commercial agreements and treaties and welcom ambassadors. Everything else was subject to senate oversight. Even the treaties he negotiated were subject to ratification by the senate. The other real power of the presidency, that he was CIC of the military, was absolutly worthless for most of our nations history because there WAS no military to speak of. Our founders had strong feelings about standing armies and the negative effect they have, and for the vast majority of this nations history those concerns were considered valid. It was not until after WWII that we actually kept a standing military with significant offensive capability. Up until then we mostly kept defensive forces. 
 
 Since WWII, the presidents office has gained considerable power with the maintenance of a standing, offensive military. We have also seen expansion in executive power in other areas...ALWAYS during wartime (or "police action" time if you prefer).
